SMART for the North West Recovery Hub
events.description: Open to all, Partnership meeting (worker-led), Thursday, 1pm- 3pm. SMART Recovery (SMART) is a science-based programme to help people manage their recovery from any type of addictive behaviour. This includes addictive behaviour with substances such as alcohol, nicotine or drugs, or compulsive behaviours such as gambling, sex, eating, shopping, self-harming and so on. SMART stands for ‘Self Management And Recovery Training’. www.smartrecovery.org.uk/‎

events.name: SMART@ the North East Hub
events.description: Open to all, Partnership meeting. 11am- 12.30pm. SMART Recovery (SMART) is a science-based programme to help people manage their recovery from any type of addictive behaviour. This includes addictive behaviour with substances such as alcohol, nicotine or drugs, or compulsive behaviours such as gambling, sex, eating, shopping, self-harming and so on. SMART stands for ‘Self Management And Recovery Training’. www.smartrecovery.org.uk/‎

events.name: SMART @ Serenity cafe
events.description: Peer Led, Open to all, 1pm-2.30pm. SMART Recovery (SMART) is a science-based programme to help people manage their recovery from any type of addictive behaviour. This includes addictive behaviour with substances such as alcohol, nicotine or drugs, or compulsive behaviours such as gambling, sex, eating, shopping, self-harming and so on. SMART stands for ‘Self Management And Recovery Training’. www.smartrecovery.org.uk/‎

events.name: SMART Family and Friends @ VOCAL (ALTERNATE WEEKS)
events.description: Open to the family and friends of addicts. Meetings take place on Tuesdays 2pm – 3.30pm one week and 6pm – 7.30pm the next – PLEASE contact prior to attending.The SMART Recovery Family & Friends (F&F) Programme offers an evidence-based approach to support individuals with a loved one struggling with addiction. SMART F&F includes tools from Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Rational Emotive Behaviour Therapy in combination with the highly acclaimed CRAFT (Community Reinforcement and Family Training) programme. The programme is designed to help those affected by a loved one’s addictive behaviour to learn new ways of dealing with the challenges, thoughts and emotions that they experience. The programme looks at areas including Positive Communication, Disabling the Enabling, Trust and Self Care. SMART F&F will help participants to view their own behaviours, challenge their thinking and find more effective ways to interact with their loved one, as well as learning ways to empower themselves.

events.name: SMART Family and Friends @ VOCAL (ALTERNATE WEEKS)
events.description: Open to the family and friends of addicts. Meetings take place on Tuesdays in the afternoon 2pm – 3.30pm one week and 6pm – 7.30pm the next – PLEASE contact prior to attending.The SMART Recovery Family & Friends (F&F) Programme offers an evidence-based approach to support individuals with a loved one struggling with addiction. SMART F&F includes tools from Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Rational Emotive Behaviour Therapy in combination with the highly acclaimed CRAFT (Community Reinforcement and Family Training) programme. The programme is designed to help those affected by a loved one’s addictive behaviour to learn new ways of dealing with the challenges, thoughts and emotions that they experience. The programme looks at areas including Positive Communication, Disabling the Enabling, Trust and Self Care. SMART F&F will help participants to view their own behaviours, challenge their thinking and find more effective ways to interact with their loved one, as well as learning ways to empower themselves.

events.name: NA @ Just for today
events.description: Meetings are for addicts and those who suspect they have a problem only. 12pm. Narcotics Anonymous is for those with major drug problems. Recovering addicts run it and help each other stay clean. It involves complete abstinence from all drugs. It doesn’t matter what or how much you used, who your connections were or what you have done in the past, only in what you want to do about your problem.

events.description: Open to all, Children welcome. 1-2pm. Narcotics Anonymous is for those with major drug problems. Recovering addicts run it and help each other stay clean. It doesn’t matter what or how much you used, who your connections were or what you have done in the past, only in what you want to do about your problem.

events.name: Acupuncture @North East recovery hub
events.description: Ear acupuncture clinic which helps with many of the different problems associated with changing or stopping your drug use.  It particularly helps to:   •	Reduce and alleviate withdrawal symptoms •	Decrease cravings for drugs •	Relieve tension, anxiety and stress •	Aid relaxation and sleep •	Clear the mind, build energy and give a sense of wellbeing.

events.name: Cooking Class @ North east recovery hub
events.description: 8 week cooking course designed to support those in recovery to:   •	Cook healthy meals on a budget •	Learn new skills in the kitchen •	Cook with food grown in our organic garden •	Sit down and enjoy your meal after cooking. From 13:00 to 16:00

events.name: Swim/Gym @ North east recovery hub
events.description: Meet at NE hub reception   Regular exercise can support your recovery from addiction:   •         improved sense of well being •         maintaining healthy body and mind •         raising self-esteem •         having fun •         building routine & structure into your week   You will have the opportunity to make use of our access to local Edinburgh Leisure Centres where you can use the facilities for £1

events.name: Yoga @ North east recovery hub
events.description: Yoga is an ancient form of exercise that focuses on strength, flexibility and breathing to boost physical and mental wellbeing. The main components of yoga are postures (a series of movements designed to increase strength and flexibility) and breathing. Yoga is a safe and effective way to increase physical activity, especially strength, flexibility and balance.  It’s also a fantastic way to relieve stress, anxiety and support relaxation.

events.name: Cooking Class @ North east recovery hub
events.description: 8 week cooking course designed to support those in recovery to:   •	Cook healthy meals on a budget •	Learn new skills in the kitchen •	Cook with food grown in our organic garden •	Sit down and enjoy your meal after cooking. From 13:00 - 16:00

events.name: Creative Writing @ North east recovery hub
events.description: 10 week writing course, you can expect:   •         Poems •         Short Stories •         Writing “Goodbye” letter to substance misuse •         Games and freestyle sessions. From 13:30 - 15:00

events.name: SMART Family and Friends @ LEAP
events.description: Open to families and friends of addicts, partnership meeting (worker-led), 6.30pm – 8pm. The SMART Recovery Family & Friends (F&F) Programme offers an evidence-based approach to support individuals with a loved one struggling with addiction. SMART F&F includes tools from Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Rational Emotive Behaviour Therapy in combination with the highly acclaimed CRAFT (Community Reinforcement and Family Training) programme. The programme is designed to help those affected by a loved one’s addictive behaviour to learn new ways of dealing with the challenges, thoughts and emotions that they experience. The programme looks at areas including Positive Communication, Disabling the Enabling, Trust and Self Care. SMART F&F will help participants to view their own behaviours, challenge their thinking and find more effective ways to interact with their loved one, as well as learning ways to empower themselves.

events.name: Leith Active Recovery Club
events.description: 12.45- 1.45 pm ALTERNATE MONDAYS ONLY: PLEASE CONTACT 0131 554 7516 or vanessa.cousins@blue yonder.co.uk. Club for people in recovery which organises subsidised social events, outings and educational courses.

events.name: Choose Life @ Simpson House
events.description: This is a group that offers hope to those overwhelmed with the despair of life. We can help you - And you can help others Do you or have you had a problem with drugs / alcohol? Are you or have you felt suicidal / attempted suicide? Are you looking for support? Do you want to help others? We can help you With support within a confidential and safe group environment. Meet with other people who have had similar experiences. And you can help others Help us to learn from your life experiences what could help and support others. Shape the way that services support people affected by suicide. Find ways to prevent suicide and raise public awareness. Explore, apply and evaluate the use of online tools and social media as a means to enhance outreach and support provision for those at risk of suicide. The group meets at Simpson House every Thursday from 10.30 till 12.00 followed by lunch. Feel free to just come along or contact us before hand to find out more. http://www.simpson-house.org/chooselifegroup.htm

events.name: Good Grub @ Serenity
events.description: 3pm - 4pm @ Serenity Good Grub group for people to explore their relationship with food in recovery

events.name: Diazepam and Me @ North East hub
events.description: 11-12.30pm Tuesday, A 4 week information and participation session focussing on the use of Diazepam. The following topics will be explored: • Tell me what you know (facts and myths) •Timeline (my use) • Physiological/ Sleep hygiene •Exploring Sleep and Memory problems • What do I want? (changes / barriers) • Next Steps (what have I learnt)

events.name: SMART@ the North East Hub (friday)
events.description: Open to all, Partnership meeting. 10.30am- 12pm. SMART Recovery (SMART) is a science-based programme to help people manage their recovery from any type of addictive behaviour. This includes addictive behaviour with substances such as alcohol, nicotine or drugs, or compulsive behaviours such as gambling, sex, eating, shopping, self-harming and so on. SMART stands for ‘Self Management And Recovery Training’. www.smartrecovery.org.uk/

events.name: Progress to Success @ North East Hub
events.description: Tuesday 11-12.30 This is a 7 week group work course which is run in the North East hub in collaboration with Access to Industry (Transition). This course is designed to support your recovery by allowing you the chance to explore how you cope with the practical and emotional areas of your life.  Completion of this course can also count towards an accredited qualification!  The course will cover the following subjects: Building self esteem and confidence; Communication; Stress and Coping; Team work; Time Management & Prioritising; Life and work values; Transferable skills

events.name: Ready Steady Change @ North East Recovery Hub
events.description: 10 Week course supports individuals who are working on their recovery from addiction, and allows them to explore how addiction has affected them and how they can move their life forward.  The subjects explored in this course support individuals to stay in recovery, and make further progress towards a substance free life. Topics covered:•	Moving Into Recovery; • Triggers; • Goal Setting; • Exploring Boredom; • Understanding Anger; • Self Talk; • Drug Awareness & New Trends; • Anxiety and Stress; • Getting Motivated to Change; • Hopes and Fears; •Health and Wellbeing

events.name: SMART Tools-workshop @ North East Hub
events.description: Open to all, Partnership meeting (worker-led), 11.00 – 12.00. This group is for people using the SMART programme to look in depth at some of the tools and techniques from the programme. (please note this is not a SMART Recovery Meeting, but a learning workshop)

events.name: Yoga for Recovery @ serenity
events.description: Group Yoga. 8pm- 9.30pm every Thursday

events.name: Yoga @ North East Hub (Monday 9.30-10.30)
events.description: Yoga is an ancient form of exercise that focuses on strength, flexibility and breathing to boost physical and mental wellbeing. The main components of yoga are postures (a series of movements designed to increase strength and flexibility) and breathing. Yoga is a safe and effective way to increase physical activity, especially strength, flexibility and balance.  Its also a fantastic way to relieve stress, anxiety and support relaxation. Note - Part of the North East Hub group work programme. Please make contact by dropping in during opening hours or calling to arrange a place.

events.name: Creative Art @ North East recovery hub
events.description: This course is to promote working creatively while still focusing on topics relevant in your recovery. Even if you have never felt artistic you will be able to learn new creative skills and build confidence within your creative ability. Examples of things you can do: • Drawing and Paining • Mask Making • Lino Cuts and Printing • Individual projects. From 13:30-15:00

events.name: Sorted Project on the Barge (Wed 1 pm)
events.description: This established recovery group meets every Wednesday on the Union Canal on a wide beam canal boat. Join us for healthy social networking, training and volunteering, soup making, crafting and working on your personal recovery journal. Help yourself to tea and coffee. The barge has central heating, toilet facilities, a kitchen and a great atmosphere. Learn how to sail the barge and join this unique and positive community every Wednesday. There are two departure times. 10am and 1pm. Meet us at the Canal Basin at Fountain Bridge near Leamington Lift Bridge. The Union Canal - the fastest way to slow down :) Places are limited so please call Karen to confirm a place 07425 147635

events.name: Co-Dependents Anonymous (CoDA)
events.description: Sunday, 1pm- 2.30 Co-Dependents Anonymous (CoDA) is a set of informal self-help groups made up of men and women with a common interest in working through the problems that co-dependency (inability to maintain healthy and nurturing relationships with ourselves and others) has caused in their lives. CoDA is based on AA (Alcoholics Anonymous) and uses an adapted version of their Twelve Steps and Traditions as a central part of its suggested programme of recovery.

events.name: CA @ Friday Evening
events.description: Friday 6 -7.30 pm. Cocaine Anonymous brings together people to share their experience, strength and hope to help each other stay free from cocaine and all other mind-altering substances. We use the excellent, tried and tested Twelve Step Recovery Programme.

events.name: Celebrate Recovery
events.description:
We meet every Thursday of the year from seven till 9.30 at the Hub Church of Scotland 6 Ravenscoft Street EH178QJ.
We are a Christian based AA styled programme for males and females struggling with hurts hangups and habits.
Group consists of 30 minutes of chat and catch up then some worship and teaching then a group for men and women which lasts for an hour.
All welcome of faith and no faith.
Contact Cammy on 07838912361 for more details.

events.name: TGIF (Thank God it's Friday) Gym group
Adult children of alcoholics (Tuesday)
events.description:
Tuesday, 7.15-9pm. Adult Children of Alcoholics is an anonymous program of women and men who grew up in alcoholic or otherwise dysfunctional homes. We discover how childhood affected us in the past and influences us in the present. We meet with each other in a mutually respectful, safe environment and acknowledge our common experiences. We take positive action by practising the Twelve Steps, focusing on The Solution, and we find freedom from the past and a way to improve our lives today. 

http://www.adultchildrenofalcoholics.co.uk/Home.php 
For general enquiries about ACA UK, please send an email to info@acoa.uk or call us on 01590 610 936

events.name: Adult Children of Alcoholics (Thursday)
events.description:
Thursday, 7.15-9pm. 12 Steps Workbook Meeting. Adult Children of Alcoholics is an anonymous program of women and men who grew up in alcoholic or otherwise dysfunctional homes. We discover how childhood affected us in the past and influences us in the present. We meet with each other in a mutually respectful, safe environment and acknowledge our common experiences. We take positive action by practising the Twelve Steps, focusing on The Solution, and we find freedom from the past and a way to improve our lives today. 
http://www.adultchildrenofalcoholics.co.uk/Home.php 
For general enquiries about ACA UK, please send an email to info@acoa.uk or call us on 01590 610 936

events.name: SMART @ South West hub
events.description:
Open to all, Partnership meeting (worker-led), Monday, 11am- 12.30pm (meeting generally does NOT run on bank holidays). Please ask at green (recovery hub) reception desk. Zero Substance - participants CANNOT have used drugs or alcohol on the day of attendance. Please do not attend if, for example, you have been drinking.
SMART Recovery (SMART) is a science-based programme to help people manage their recovery from any type of addictive behaviour. This includes addictive behaviour with substances such as alcohol, nicotine or drugs, or compulsive behaviours such as gambling, sex, eating, shopping, self-harming and so on. SMART stands for ‘Self Management And Recovery Training’. www.smartrecovery.org.uk/

services.name: North East Recovery Hub
services.description: The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs.
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: Alcohol, Drugs, and BBV Social Work Team
services.description:
The Team is a service for people 16 years and over who have problems with drugs and/or alcohol and other complex needs. People must be willing and able to work in a planned way to address their drug and alcohol problems. This could mean looking at other parts of their life which may be getting in the way of their recovery. They work with people for around 16 weeks.
Enquiries can be made during normal office hours. Outside of these hours and on public holidays, the Emergency Social Work Service can be contacted on 0800 731 6969.
services.support_options: 1 to 1 professional support
services.referral_method: Come to the recovery hub in your area or ask your GP, Social worker, or any professional who works with you to make a referral to the service.

services.name: Bethany Christian Centre
services.description: Bethany Christian Centre aims, through a supported residential community, to assist individuals in their recovery from an addictive lifestyle. The Centre provides access to a selection of recovery programmes including structured group-work, one-to-one support, recreation, work activities and training
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Residential services; Some men only services
services.referral_method: For further information please contact the project.

services.name: Anchor Project
services.description: This service provides temporary, 24 hour supported accommodation for up to seven men recovering from problems with drugs and / or alcohol . Service users must be alcohol or drug free for three months before their stay. They must also willing to address the issues around their problems.
services.support_options: Residential services; Some men only services
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: Broomhouse Youth Befriending Project
services.description: This Project offers one to one support for young people aged 5 -16 years who are affected by a parent's use of alcohol or drugs. Each young person meets with a volunteer befriender for two hours each week. They can talk about issues which are important for the young person. There is also the chance to try new activities.
services.support_options: Help for families and friends; Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a referral form.

services.name: CARDS
services.description: CARDS is a volunteer service which works with people in Leith who have a history of alcohol problems.  We help people who are have little or no support for their mental, physical and emotional health. We can work with people who are still drinking. Our team also works with people who want to change. A diagnosis of Alcohol Related Brain Damage is not needed to access this service.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; Peer support; Leisure and social groups; Some men only services
services.referral_method: Cards operate on a first come, first served basis. Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: Circle Harbour Project
services.description:
Circle's Harbour Project offers a voluntary support service for children and families affected by parents' use of alcohol or drugs. We help parents to: manage their children's routines and behaviour; access other services including drug agencies; counselling, employment and education, housing officers and social workers; fill out forms and answer letters. 
We also support other family members who are involved in the children's lives.   The project directly supports children through giving a listening ear and helping them to get to school and out of school activities. Workers are based in Pilton and Wester Hailes but the service covers the whole city.
services.support_options: Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children
services.referral_method: Contact the local hub service and ask for an appointment with a Circle worker.

services.name: Edinburgh Young Carers
services.description: The project works with young carers in Edinburgh. We offer support to young people affected by their parent's use of drugs or alcohol, disability, or health condition. We help young people cope with the stress and complexities of their home life. We offer one to one support, group work, trips away and information.
services.support_options: Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children
services.referral_method: Contact us directly to arrange a meeting with a member of staff.
services.business_times_extra_info: Group sessions will take place in the evenings at varying times.	Wheelchair accessible office

services.name: ELCA Counselling Service
services.description: This service works with people aged 18 years and over who are worried about their own drinking. It also supports people who are worred about the drinking of a family member, partner or friend. It provides Drop-In services, advice, information and one to one counselling. It is based in Clifton Terrace. It has bases in Craigmillar, Gracemount, Wester Hailes, Sighthill, Leith, Pennywell / Crewe, Kirkliston, South Queensferry.  It also offers services its Women's Service at Oxgangs and the Edinburgh Rape Crisis Centre.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional supportHelp for families and friends; Choice of gender of worker; Some women only services
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.
services.business_times_extra_info:
Answering machine outwith these hours. 
ELCA's Clifton Terrace premises are not accessible as they are flights of stairs.  However, our locally based services are fully accessible.  Please contact for details.

services.name: Genesis project
services.description: The Genesis Project provides housing support for around fifteen men or women struggling with drugs and / or alcohol problems.   They may live in their own houses or in a B & B.
services.support_options: Residential services; Some men only services
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: Harm Reduction Team
services.description:
Low Threshold Medication Programme for injecting drug users via drop - in: substitute prescribing, motivational interviewing, relapse prevention and clinical psychology. Self - referral is encouraged for clients motivated to change. Once stable, referral to other support and treatment options. 
Needle Exchange drop - in. 
Women's Clinic and Midwife Service: family planning and sexual health service for clients involved in the sex industry or who have problems with drugs or alcohol. 
Dental Service: drop - in and appointment drug users unable to access dental care. 
Wound Care Clinic: for clients with drug-related skin care problems. 
NEON - Needle Exchange Outreach Network: support to pharmacies and drug agencies offering needle exchange and outreach services. 
Training on harm reduction for individuals and organisations as per HRT training manual.
services.support_options: 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Injecting equipment; C:card
services.referral_method: You do not need to contact them to arrange a place. Drop in to the centre whenever the service is open.
services.business_times_extra_info: Main Reception: Monday - Friday, 9am - 4pm.  The Exchange: Monday and Thursday 10.00 am - 4.30 pm, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday 12.30 pm - 4.30 pm. Needle exchange drop - in  Monday to Friday, 12.30 - 4.30pm.

services.name: Residential Rehabilitation Referral Team
services.description:
This is a service for people 18 years and over, who have problems with drugs or alcohol, and have already tried to get help to stop using, but are still struggling with their addiction. You will work with the team to find out what help you need, and why you want to change. 
If rehabilitation is recommended for you, then you will decide together what rehab options are best for you. The team will help you get ready to go to rehab, make sure the process is working for you, and help you when you come out. 
Most places are for single people, but there are also some places for parents and children.
services.support_options: Residential services
services.referral_method: Your doctor or social worker can refer you to the Residential Rehabilitation Referral Team (3RT). If you don't have a social worker, you can  contact Social Care Direct for an assessment.

services.name: LEAP (Lothians and Edinburgh Abstinence project)
services.description: LEAP is an intensive programme for up to twenty people who want to stop drinking or using drugs.  It is a therapeutic community.  It supports people for three months, with structured activities every day.  These include group work, workshops, presentations, education, and training.  There are also recreation and relaxation activities. Detoxification can also be provided from modest amounts of drugs or alcohol.  People who take part in the programme can access supported housing at Randolph Crescent Hostel, run by the City of Edinburgh Council.  Access to Industry also works with people on the programme, to help them start training or education, or to get a job, as part of their recovery plan.  People who complete the programme can get support for up to two years after they finish.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; Peer support; Residential services; Some women only services; Some men only services
services.referral_method: Ask your GP, Social worker, or any professional who works with you to make a referral to the service.

services.name: North East Recovery Hub
services.description: The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Injecting equipment	C:card; Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children; Choice of gender of worker; Some women only services
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: Rankeillor Initiative
services.description: The Rankeillor Initiative have supported accommodation for men in recovery from drug / alcohol misuse in shared flats in central Edinburgh.Â Â We also give support for people in their own homes in Edinburgh to address issues around their substance misuse.
services.support_options: 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Moving on – education, training and work opportunities
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly for more information or to ask for a place.

services.name: North West Recovery Hub
services.description: The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Injecting equipment; Choice of gender of worker
services.referral_method: Attend one of the drop in sessions.

services.name: Scottish Families Affected by Drugs (helpline)
services.description: We facilitate a network of family support groups across Scotland. These groups are for relatives, partners and friends who are affected by a loved one's drugs misuse. We provide a welcoming and non judgemental environment for sharing stories and experiences. We also provide information to friends and families, to help them support their relative and to help themselves. We do this through our Helpline webchat, phone and email service.  We provide direct 1-1 professional suppport via our Telehealth Service available for family members who cannot access services due to being rural and remote either geographically or physically.  Our Telehealth service is provided either via phone or via our online Telehealth platform providing face to face video contact,, webchat or peer support through online forums.  We also provide counselling support services for individuals who have lost a loved one as a result of a drugs related death within the last 3 years.  All services are accessible via contacting the Helpline.
services.support_options: Help for families and friends
services.business_times_extra_info: Outwith these times and at peak times a voicemail can be left and you will receive a callback wtihin 24 hours

services.name: Serenity Cafe
services.description: We provide a safe drug and alcohol free social space where people can support each other and strengthen their recovery. We provide cafe and community support volunteer opportunities. Members and volunteers are entitled to discounted food and drinks and non-members (the public) are also welcome to use the cafe at slightly higher prices.  The cafe provides access to Trained Volunteer Recovery Coaches and Financial Inclusion workers. The cafe has also a full programme of activities, including learning programs, social/hobby group as well as fellowship and recovery support groups, and a women's project.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Moving on – education, training and work opportunities; Help for families and friends; Leisure and social groups; Choice of gender of worker; Some women only services; Some men only services
services.referral_method: Drop in whenever the cafe is open.
services.business_times_extra_info: Additional groups and activities often running outside these hours. No appointment is necessary. Disabled access, with disabled toilets

services.name: Simpson House Counselling and Recovery service
services.description: Simpson House Counselling & Recovery provides a counselling service for people aged 16 and over affected by drugs. We work in Edinburgh and in Edinburgh Prison. We offer one - to - one counselling and couple counselling. We also have various groups including a Choose Life Group. We offer full support to people who have used the service in the past, and who now want to volunteer with Simpson House and CrossReach services.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Help for families and friends; Choice of gender of worker
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place. You cannot be referred by a professional.
services.business_times_extra_info: Monday and Wednesday, 9am - 8pm. Tuesday, Thursday and Friday, 9am - 5pm.

services.name: Sorted Project
services.description: The Sorted Project works across Edinburgh and Lothian supporting people over the age of 18 and in recovery from substance (drugs/alcohol) dependency and associated mental health issues. Most of our clients are unemployed and their issues are a major barrier to mainstream employability and employment. We work in partnership with a range of established voluntary and statutory organisations to provide support in moving closer to mainstream employability agencies. Referrals come from addiction treatment agencies, mental health agencies, social work, NHS and client/peer recommendations. Sorted provides group and one to one personal development, confidence building and meaningful training and volunteering opportunities.  Meetings can be held acros the city to suit the participants.  Sorted delivers group work with organisations such as the South East Recovery Hub, Castle Project and CHAI.  Sorted provides a unique recovery based canal boat project which is a safe and positive environment where referred participants can train and volunteer in all aspects of canal boating including the Helmsman Certificate, First Aid Certificate, Hospitality, and Food Hygiene.  It provides a safe and welcoming space, great atmosphere, peer support and the added beneftis of the calming and beneficial canal and countryside location.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Moving on – education, training and work opportunities; Leisure and social groups
services.business_times_extra_info:
Monday outreach 9am to 6pm 
Tuesday South East Recovery Hub Castle Project 11am to 1pm group. 
Wednesday 10am to 1pm Canal Boat Project.  
Wednesday 2pm to 5pm Canal Boat Project.  
Thursday Outreach 9am to 6pm and 
Friday outreach 9am to 6pm.  	
Fully accessible entrance at The Melting Pot with a lift and fully accessible toilets

services.name: South West Recovery Hub (Westerhailes)
services.description:
The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs. 
It has two venues for the drop in sessions. To get help via the Recovery Hub your first visit should either be to ELS House, 555 Gorgie Road or The Healthy Living Centre, 30 Harvesters Way (green reception / Health Agency Desk).
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Injecting equipment	C:card; Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children; Choice of gender of worker
services.referral_method: Attend one of the drop in sessions.

services.name: South East Recovery hub
services.description: The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Injecting equipment; C:card; Choice of gender of worker
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place, or drop in during opening hours.

services.name: Transitions
services.description: Access to Industry supports unemployed people in Edinburgh to move into work. They have a number of programmes. The Transition programme works with people recovering from misuse of drugs or alcohol. The Passport programme works with young people up to age 21 years who are leaving care. They also help offenders of any age. They work with Edinburgh College to provide access to college courses, with extra support to maintain the place.
services.support_options: 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Moving on – education, training and work opportunities; Leisure and social groups; Some women only services
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: VOCAL (Family Support Addictions)
services.description: This service is for people aged 18 years and over who care for and are affected by someone else's use of drugs or alcohol. Service users can have one to one emotional support and counselling. There are monthly peer support groups on the first Tuesday and first Thursday of the month. Training for carers and families affected by alcohol use is run in partnership with NHS Lothian. There are also opportunities for carers to take a short break.
services.support_options: Help for families and friends
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly to ask for a place.

services.name: Willow Project
services.description: Supporting women to grow: We provide a wide range of support services if you are a woman who is over 17 and involved with any part of the criminal justice system.  Most women attend at least twice weekly from 10am - 4pm, as well as key work support. Child care arrangements can be made so that you can take part in these services, and bus tickets, breakfast and lunch are provided.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Moving on – education, training and work opportunities; Leisure and social groups; Some women only services

services.name: South West Recovery Hub (Gorgie/Dalry)
services.description:
The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs. 
It has two venues for the drop in sessions. To get help via the Recovery Hub your first visit should either be to ELS House, 555 Gorgie Road or The Healthy Living Centre, 30 Harvesters Way (green reception / Health Agency Desk).
services.support_options: Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children
services.referral_method: Attend one of the drop in sessions.

services.name: Crew
services.description: Crew 2000 offers services for drug users and provides outreach, harm reduction and education and prevention service to major music festivals. Our drop-in shop on Cockburn Street provides information and advice about drug, alcohol, and sexual health. The shop also has C - card and blood borne virus testing services (includinge HIV / AIDS). Drop-in services are for people aged 12 upwards. Support services for people aged 16 plus: one to one recovery work (up to 6 sessions), one to one drug counselling (up to 30 sessions), carer and relationship counselling (up to 6 sessions) and mindfulness, SMART and acupuncture groups by trained and qualified practitioners.  Online info and support available (chat room by appointment) www.mycrew.org.uk.  We also offer training for professionals and carers on drugs issues, policy consultancy, event welfare service and an expert witness service for people charged with drug offences.
services.support_options: Group support/ treatment; 1 to 1 professional support; Peer support; Help for families and friends; C:card
services.referral_method: Contact by telephone, online www.mycrew.org or drop in directly during shop opening times to ask for a place.
services.business_times_extra_info:
Drop-in is accessible from Cockburn St, access via stairs to counselling and recovery work rooms.
Office hours (telephone) 9.30am-5pm. Drop in as above. 
The advice shop is open Mon-Sat 1pm to 5pm except Thursday 3pm-7pm. 
Counselling available until 7 pm on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

services.name: Sunflower Garden
services.description: Sunflower Garden provides a range of support for children and young people who are affected by the use of drugs and alcohol in their families. It works with children for P1 to S2. Its Befriending Service is for children and young people who are affected by parental substance use. Befriending is available from 5 to 16 years old.
services.support_options: Support for parents who have drug and alcohol issues and their children
services.referral_method: Contact the service directly or any of the hub services to ask for a place.

services.name: South West Recovery Hub @ Oxgangs
services.description: The Recovery Hub is a one - stop shop where you can access a wide range of alcohol and drug services and support. It brings together a range of support services for people with problems associated with alcohol and drugs. It has two venues for the drop in sessions. To get help via the Recovery Hub your first visit should either be to ELS House, 555 Gorgie Road or The Healthy Living Centre, 30 Harvesters Way (green reception / Health Agency Desk).
services.referral_method: Attend one of the drop in sessions

groups.name: Cocaine Anonymous
groups.description: Cocaine Anonymous brings together people to share their experience, strength and hope to help each other stay free from cocaine and all other mind-altering substances. We use the excellent, tried and tested Twelve Step Recovery Programme.

groups.name: Activities @ Serenity Cafe
groups.description: We are Scotland's first Recovery Café, run by people in recovery for people in recovery, and public customers who want good value, good quality food in a relaxed space

groups.name: Groups at the North East Recovery Hub
groups.description: This is a programme of group activities run by Turning Point Scotland for users of the North East Recovery Hub (in Leith). All of these groups are led by professional workers. To use them (unless you are already working with a nurse, social worker or addictons worker), you need to make contact through the hub drop-in (no appointment necessary) or phone for information.

groups.name: Chose Life @ Simpson House
groups.description:
This is a group that offers hope to those overwhelmed with the despair of life.

We can help you - And you can help others
 
Do you or have you had a problem with drugs / alcohol?
 
Are you or have you felt suicidal / attempted suicide?
 
Are you looking for support? Do you want to help others?
 
We can help you
 
With support within a confidential and safe group environment.
 
Meet with other people who have had similar experiences.
 
And you can help others
 
Help us to learn from your life experiences what could help and support others.
 
Shape the way that services support people affected by suicide.
 
Find ways to prevent suicide and raise public awareness.
 
Explore, apply and evaluate the use of online tools and social media as a means to enhance outreach and support provision for those at risk of suicide.

The group meets at Simpson House every Thursday from 10.30 till 12.00 followed by lunch. Feel free to just come along or contact us before hand to find out more. 

http://www.simpson-house.org/chooselifegroup.htm

groups.name: Narcotics Anonymous
groups.description: Narcotics Anonymous is for those with major drug problems. Recovering addicts run it and help each other stay clean. It involves complete abstinence from all drugs. It doesn’t matter what or how much you used, who your connections were or what you have done in the past, only in what you want to do about your problem.

groups.name: Alcoholics Anonymous
groups.description: Alcoholics Anonymous has over 50 meetings a week in and around Edinburgh. We help anyone with a serious alcohol problem. Through mutual support, sufferers help each other to cope with their problem.

groups.name: SMART Recovery Groups
groups.description: SMART Recovery (SMART) is a science-based programme to help people manage their recovery from any type of addictive behaviour. This includes addictive behaviour with substances such as alcohol, nicotine or drugs, or compulsive behaviours such as gambling, sex, eating, shopping, self-harming and so on. SMART stands for ‘Self Management And Recovery Training’. www.smartrecovery.org.uk/‎

groups.name: SMART Family and Friends
groups.description:
The SMART Recovery Family & Friends (F&F) Programme offers an evidence-based approach to support individuals with a loved one struggling with addiction.

SMART F&F includes tools from Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Rational Emotive Behaviour Therapy in combination with the highly acclaimed CRAFT (Community Reinforcement and Family Training) programme. The programme is designed to help those affected by a loved one’s addictive behaviour to learn new ways of dealing with the challenges, thoughts and emotions that they experience.

The programme looks at areas including Positive Communication, Disabling the Enabling, Trust and Self Care. SMART F&F will help participants to view their own behaviours, challenge their thinking and find more effective ways to interact with their loved one, as well as learning ways to empower themselves.

groups.name: Co-Dependents Anonymous
groups.description:
Co-Dependents Anonymous (CoDA) is a set of informal self-help groups made up of men and women with a common interest in working through the problems that co-dependency has caused in their lives. CoDA is based on AA (Alcoholics Anonymous) and uses an adapted version of their Twelve Steps and Traditions as a central part of its suggested programme of recovery.
 
To attend CoDA meetings, all you need is the willingness to work at having healthy relationships. This means that all kinds of people attend meetings. Individual members can and do have differing political, religious and other affiliations, but since these are not relevant to the business of recovery from co-dependency, no comment is made about them.
 
All meetings begin with an introduction which usually includes the Twelve Steps and Traditions, a welcome to newcomers, and an explanation of the format the meeting will take. There may be a speaker, or a reading of a Step or a topic. The meeting is then open for people to share their experiences, feelings and recovery with the group. There is no obligation to share if you do not wish to, whether you are a newcomer or a long-established member. Each meeting usually incorporates a collection to cover the expenses of the group (eg hire of the meeting room) but CoDA is non-profit making. The meeting will end with a special prayer, called the Serenity Prayer. After the meeting, newcomers who would like more information can use this time to have their questions answered by more established members.

Am I Co-Dependent?
 
You may be wondering: 'Am I Co-Dependent?' 'What is Co-Dependence?' Many of us want precise definitions and diagnostic criteria before we will decide. At CoDA, we respectfully allow psychiatric and psychological professionals to provide these, but what we do offer from our own experience are characteristic attitudes and behaviour patterns that describe what our co-dependent histories have been like.
 
We believe that recovery begins with an honest self-diagnosis. We came to accept our inability to maintain healthy and nurturing relationships with ourselves and others. We began to recognise that the cause lay in long-standing destructive patterns of living. We have found these patterns to fall into four major categories: denial, low self-esteem, compliance and control. The checklist of patterns and characteristics is offered as a tool to aid in self-evaluation. It may be particularly helpful to newcomers as they begin to understand co-dependence. It may also aid those who have been in recovery for a while to determine what traits still need attention and transformation.
 
After completing this checklist we suggest that you continue attending CoDA meetings for several weeks. Listen to the similarities and not the differences. Search out members of the fellowship you believe you can trust and discuss your checklist answers with them. If you come to accept that you are, indeed, co-dependent, then you will be ready to begin the Twelve Steps of recovery, and to seek a sponsor to guide you through the process.

groups.name: Adult Children of Alcoholics and Dysfunctional Families UK
groups.description:
Adult Children of Alcoholics is an anonymous program of women and men who grew up in alcoholic or otherwise dysfunctional homes. 

We discover how childhood affected us in the past and influences us in the present. We meet with each other in a mutually respectful, safe environment and acknowledge our common experiences. 

We take positive action by practising the Twelve Steps, focusing on The Solution, and we find freedom from the past and a way to improve our lives today.
